There is a significant propensity to arrive at 1,000 or more civilian deaths during the period stated. According to Human Rights Watch's 'World Report 2018' released in the beginning of this year, President Duterte’s extrajudicial war on drugs that began in June 2016, had resulted in the killing of more than 12,000 drug suspects by the end of 2017 (i.e. 12,000 civilians systematically killed by armed groups - as defined above - over 1.5 years). We do not know if the death toll is continuing at that rate. However, there are factors/developments that can drive a significantly high death rate.  In addition to the open-source information shared by cdob63, other media reports in June 2018 indicated that President Rodrigo Duterte (after consulting with the police and intelligence community) said he was considering arming community leaders, known as 'barangay' captains, with handguns. The intention is to mobilise the country's barangay captains to help fight crime and drugs. President Duterte said that  he vowed to provide the same legal protection to barangay captains as he did soldiers or police, and they “will never go to jail” if they shot suspected criminals in the performance of their duty. There are currently 42,000 barangay captains in the country. The handguns would be provided for free, or private purchases subsidized.
